Synthesis the new solegel derived compound of nanoeparticles Hydroxyaptite (CaHA). CaHA shows high qm of Congo red adsorption as 487.80 mg g 1 in comparision with others. Fitting well the adsorption isotherms data with the Langmuir model. Kinetic data well fitted with the pseudoesecond order equation. Exothermic and spontaneous adsorption process as DG < 0 and DH < 0.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 21 March 2017 Received in revised form 8 July 2017 Accepted 19 September 2017 Available online 21 September 2017
Keywords: NanoeHydroxyApatite Congo red Solegel Kinetics Adsorption isotherms
a b s t r a c t
In this study, an effective adsorbent calcium hydroxyapatite (CaHA) having high adsorption capacity about aqueous solution of Congo red dye in ambient temperature is presented. Nano particles of CaHA were prepared through a new easy alkoxideebased solegel technique. The structural characterization of synthesized CaHAwere performed by Xeray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) analysis, thermal behavior (DTA), morphology and elemental analysis via scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The nano particle size and microestrain of CaHA were measured using modified Shcerrer equation as WilliamsoneHall method and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). XRD pattern shows hexagonal structure of the nanoeparticle CaHA with P63/m space group that the size measured through XRD and TEM methods are in good agreement as 25 nm. The equilibrium adsorption capacity (qm) for 100 ppm CR was measured to be 487.80 mg g 1 under optimal conditions. The adsorption isotherms and kinetic data well fitted with the Langmuir model and the pseudoesecond order equation with correlation coefficients of 0.9979 and 0.9902, respectively. The calculated structures of CR and its complex including Ca2þ and PO43 ions show the electrostatic interactions of anionic CR dye and Ca2þ site and hydrogen bonding of amine group and phosphate of CaHA surface. Thermodynamic parameters (DG < 0 and DH < 0) imply the exothermic and spontaneous adsorption process. Finally, the experimental results suggest that this new synthesized CaHA can be good candidate for application in the management of environmental.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The dye and organic content of wastewaters discharged industrial are generally high result in severe problems such as delaying the growth of micro organisms, increasing the chemical oxygen demand (COD), reducing light penetration, and visibility [1e3]. Synthetic dyes having stability, carcinogenic, and toxic properties such as health and visibility problems that cause not completely removed from wastewater as a worldwide major environmental problem [4]. Moreover, their metabolic processes in animals and plants make hazardous aromatic amines that cause problems of environmental pollution. Therefore, many removing techniques including chemical oxidation, adsorption, photo degradation, biodegradation, and electrochemical process are used [5e9]. However, for this purpose the conventional biological treatment processes are not so successful [10].
Congo red (sodium salt of benzidinediazo bis 1 naphthylamine 4 sulfonic acid) (CR) as a most used color in the textile industries, because of its aromatic structure shows high physicochemical, thermal and, optical stability against photo or biodegradation [11]. The good water solubility of CR makes difficult it's discoloring in wastewater and aquatic environment. Among different using methods, adsorption by organic or inorganic adsorbents has been introduced as a most simple, high efficiency, and reusability methods with ease decolorization of textile wastewaters [12]. In recent years, absorbing of different azo dyes including CR using compounds such as the, bentonite, hematite, g-Fe2O3/SiO2, CuFe2O3, nanoporous silica, mesoporous TiO2, red mud, fly ash, kaolin, leaf powder, marble powder, and activated carbon have been studied [13e17]. The problem is that most of the applied compounds have not sufficient adsorption capacities (less than 100mg/g) towards CRmolecules, therefore in recent years several novel alternative adsorbents such as calcium hydroxyapatite (CaHA) bioceramic attract growing interest because of the low cost, non toxicity, non immunogenicity, and high adsorptive capabilities to pollutants [18e25]. CaHA shows high stability in physiological conditions [26,27] that makes it a good biomaterials employing in tissue engineering [26].
CaHA possessing two different ionic C and P binding sites on the crystal surface, respectively, rich in calcium ions with positive charge and rich in phosphate ions with negative charge, respectively [28e30]. Therefore, CR as an anionic dye should be adsorbed on C sites through electrostatic interactions. The unsaturated nanoparticles of CaHA can bind with other atoms resulted in remarkable adsorption ability. Therefore it has been identified as a good absorbent for many compounds and pollutants like anionic and cationic proteins, heavy metals, phenol, and azo dyes [31e34]. Also, these biomaterials widely used through chromatography to separate different proteins and nucleic acid fragments [35]. There are several works on dyes adsorption of CaHA like disperse blue SBL [36], reactive yellow 4 [37], direct yellow 27 [38], and reactive blue 204 and methylen blue (MB) [39], although there are no report, about the adsorption of CR onto sol gel derived nanoparticles of HAp. Herein, for the first time the new synthesized sol gel derived CaHA introduced as an effective adsorbent of CR.
In this work, sol gel method because of homogeneity of product, capability to make nanoparticles, bioactivity, and low crystallinity of prepared materials with high absorption surface area chose to synthesize nanoparticles of CaHA. In followings, the synthesized nanoparticles used for removing CR in water. Finally, the sample characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, and particle size estimated by XRD and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM). It should be noted that the experimental results of absorption of CR
will be discussed in details about kinetics, equilibrium adsorption isotherms, and thermodynamic parameters.

sections.heading: 2.1. HA sol-gel synthesis & physical measurement
sections.text: Firstly as the novel part of the applied method, triethyl phosphate ((C2H5O)3PO, TEP, Fluka) was hydrolyzed for 24 h at R.T. along with the vigorous stirring. In following, an aqueous solution of 3 M Ca(NO3)2$4H2O (Merck) was added to 4 M hydrolyzed TEP (Ca/ P ¼ 1.67) slowly at a rate of 6 mL/min. Then the respect sol solution was vigorously mixed for 60 min at 80 C. Finally, a clear solution was obtained that aged at room temperature for 24 h. The progress of solegel process was gradually followed with recording the pH values of the aging sol. Next, the aged sol was dried at 150 C until a white dried gel was obtained. The uncalcined gel structure was analyzed using differential thermal analysis (DTA, Netzsch, Germany) and IR spectroscopy (Buck 500, KBr) in the range of 500e4000 cm 1. The dried gel was ground into fine powder then was heat treated at low calcination temperature 300 C for 1 h at a constant heat rate of 2 C/min. Phase identification of the calcined gel of CaHA was performed using the Xeray diffractometer (XRD, Philips, X׳pert Pro, Cu Ka) at a scanning speed of 1 2q/min from 20 to 45 . With the aid of scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S 360, OxfordeEngland), themorphology of CaHAwas recorded (Fig.1 (a)) and its Ca/P molar ratio was measured as 1.98.

sections.heading: 2.2. Particle size determination
sections.text: Particle size and micro strain of CaHA powder with the aid of Scherrer and Williamson Hall equations [40,41] were calculated. Also, particle size distribution was determined by TEM observations. TEM (Leo 912 AB Germany) was equipped with a thermionic gun and was operated at 120 kV. TEM sample were prepared as follows: the CaHA powder was ultrasonically dispersed for 2 h in absolute ethanol and afterward deposited on a carbonated copper grid.

sections.heading: 2.3. Adsorption equilibrium and kinetics measurements
sections.text:
All of the adsorption solutions in the experiment were prepared by dissolving Congo red (CR) (Merck) into ultrapure water. Each experiment was done using the fresh dilutions. In order to study the mechanism of adsorption of CR and determine the optimum adsorption conditions, certain concentrations of CaHA samples were treated in 200 mL Erlenmeyer flask containing 100 mL of CR and shaken at 300 rpm on a specified temperature. The effect of dosage was examined in the range of 0.02e0.5 mg (natural pH, contact time for 140 min, temperature at 298 K). The effect of contact timewas studied in the time range of 0e140min (dosage of 60 mg for CR, natural pH, temperature at 298 K). The effect of pH was investigated in the range of 3e10. The initial concentrations of CR rang of 20e150 mg L 1 applied to draw of adsorption equilibrium isotherms. CR adsorbed concentrations were determined using a UV Vis spectrophotometer (UNICO 2800) at its lmax ¼ 485 nm.
Equilibrium absorbance capacity (qe (mg/g)) and adsorbed amount of CR per unit mass of the adsorbent at time t were determined using the following equations:
qe ¼ (C0 Ce)V / m (1)
qt ¼ (C0 Ct)V / m (2)
Removal efficiency (%) ¼ 100 (C0 Ce) / C0 (3)
where C0, Ce, and Ct (mg/L) are initial, equilibrium, and t time concentrations of CR, respectively. V (L) is the volume of dye solution, and m (g) is the used mass of absorbent. The nanoparticles of CaHA completely adsorb CR from the pertinent solution, as its color significantly reduced after adsorption (cf. Fig. 1 (b)). To evaluate of the adsorption kinetic of CR, some experiments were carry out.

sections.heading: 2.4. Computational details
sections.text: In order to qualitative and quantitative investigation of the adsorption sites of CaHA surface the total density and atomic density deposited over the structure of CR were calculated. For this purpose the structure of all involving species in the sort of adsorption reaction: CR þ PO43 þ Ca2þ / CReHA (Adsorbed CR) optimized. The optimized schematic structure of product can be found in Fig. 1 (d). Moreover, energy calculations in the gas phase (25 C and 1 atm) within the optimized structures were performed and were corrected using the zeroepoint energy correction. The binding energies of the nonecovalent interactions between CR and phosphate and calcium ions of CaHA were corrected for the basis set superposition error (BSSE) using the Boys‒Bernardi counterpoise technique [42a]. In followings, natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses were also performed. All the calculations was performed in the framework of a density functional theory (DFT) through hybrid functional B3LYP/6e311 þ G(d, p) [42be44] using the program Gaussian 09 [45] (see Fig. 1(c) and (d)).

sections.heading: 3.1.1. XRD analysis
sections.text:
According to Fig. 2(a) the XRD pattern of CaHA sample shows the intense peaks of hydroxyapatite (HA) and impurity phase of CaO which match the ICDD standards (JCPDS). The indices of HA ((002), (210), and (211)), tri calcium phosphate (TCP) ((217) at 30.7 ), and calcium pyrophosphate (Ca2P2O7) ((100) at 26.7 ) confirm the hexagonal, rhombohedral, and monoclinic systems for them. Overall, synthesized CaHA had a good and stable crystal shape. The control of the heat treatment and aging steps of sol gel route helps to improve the polymerization process between Ca and P precursors (Eqs. sections.heading: 3.1.2. FTIR spectra
sections.text:
FTIR analysis can be used to explore the surface functional
groups of CaHA particles (Fig. 2 (b)). The as prepared gel includes amorphous HA and the reactants as OEt stretching band at 1232 and 1370 cm 1 shows the incompletion of hydrolysis of TEP (Eq. (4)), while the broadness of the OH stretching in the region 3200 3700 cm 1 and its bending band at 3555 cm 1, and the located bands at 817,1054, and 2977 cm 1 assigned to PO43 support the presence of HA in the as prepared gel [51]. The absorption bands at 746, 952, and 1441 cm 1 were attributed to NO3 in as - dried gel that identified by very hygroscopic properties of the gel that shows remaining of Ca(NO3)2 precursor in the gel. The stretching band of C¼O of CO32 group in 1630 cm 1 shows the
presence of carbonate in apatite structure that could improve the absorption property of synthesized CaHA. Also, the FTIR of calcined CaHA sample at 300 C shows the bands at 565, 1044; 1420e1460; and 3433 cm 1 attributed to sterching modes of phosphate, carbonate, and O H functional groups, respectively (see Fig. 2(b)). The observed peaks are in good agreement with the other reported data in the literature [52].

sections.text:

SEM image (Fig. 1(a)) show drastic agglomaration of nano CaHA particles. The elemental analysis of SEM proposed the Ca/P molar ratio of 1.98 with Ca5(PO4)2.53(CO3)0.47(OH) formula that confirmed the synthesize of carbonate CaHA. sections.heading: 3.2. Factors affecting CR adsorption on CaHA
sections.text:
According to the geometry optimization and surface charge distribution of CR, calculations show themain negative and positive charges placed on oxygen and nitrogen atoms, respectively (see Fig. 1(c)). The optimized structure of CR þ (Ca2þ and PO43 ) shows that Ca2þ sites tend to negatively charged oxygen atoms of CRwhile phosphate ions have interacted with positively nitrogen atoms (Fig. 1(d)). Therefore, the adsorptive removal efficiency of a nanoadsorbent governed with their electrostatic interactions to the dye molecules having aromatic groups. Theoretical results show that the product formation energy (pfe); (Epfe ¼ E product e nE reactant); of the proposed complex product (depicted in Fig. 1(d)) is negative ase15.34 kJ mol 1. Therefore, the product formation via
that nonecovalent interactions is favorable. Moreover, computed thermodynamic parameters of DG0, DH0 obtained as 17.29 and 16.81 kJ mol 1 indicate the exothermic and spontaneous adsorption process in confirmation with the measured experi-
mental data (see section 3.5; cf. Table 3). Some characteristic properties of adsorbent like size and functionalization affect on their interaction efficacy with the adsorbates molecules. However, many works show the capability of CaHA within adsorption of different compounds [53e58] as in the previous work we show the high adsorption capacity of sol gel derived HA about phthalate esters [59]. Herein, the influence of different parameters on the adsorptive removal efficiency of calcined solegelederived CaHA including nanoparticles dosage amount, initial dye concentration, pH, and contact time of the system have been studied.
3.2.1. Effect of adsorbent dosage on the removal efficiency The effect of CaHA dose over 0.02e0.5 g on the removal of CR were evaluated at 298 K. The results of Fig. 3(a) displayed the dye percentage removal increased rapidly with the increasing of adsorbent dosage, which could be assigned to the active sites and availability of more adsorption sites enhanced with increasing the amount of CaHA. The maximum equilibrium adsorption of CR (98.43%) was attained when the dosage was 0.2 g. However, the increasing of the adsorbent dosage does not show the rising of removal efficiency of CR after the equilibrium, because of saturation of the most adsorption sites, applying more amount of adsorbent just turns some of sites intowaste. According the removal efficiency results of Fig. 3(a), 0.2 g was used as the optimum adsorbent dosage for CR in the further experiments.
3.2.2. Effect of initial pH on the removal efficiency The surface charge of the absorbent as well as the ionization degree of the pollutants influenced by the pH of solution. Therefore, the effect of initial pH of a series of batch equilibrium solution on the removal efficiency were examined at 100 mg L 1 initial concentration of CR in the pH range of 5.5e11 (see Fig. 3(b)). In pH lower than 5.5, CR structure turns to acidic form with a blue color solution (pKa ¼ 3e5). Actually, the adsorption capacity of solegelederived CaHA was lower in basic and higher in acidic pH media. The maximum percentage removal of CR (98.72%) was found at pH ¼ 6. Therefore, this pH value selected as the optimal one for further adsorption studies. The observed behavior relates to the pH of CR dye solution and the point of zero charge (pHpzc) of the CaHA. CR as the sodium salt of 3,30-([1,10-biphenyl]-4,40-diyl)bis(4aminonaphthalene-1-sulfonic acid) is a potent anionic diazo dye in aqueous solution (see its optimized structure in Fig. 1(c)). The determined pHpzc value of CaHA sample was 7.2. The dye adsorption process within pH effect is depended to the anionic nature of the CR and the amphoteric nature of the hydroxyapatite surface. Therefore, according to the charge density of CR, positive charge of absorbent surface should be suitable to the removal of the dye. So, gradually increasing the pH of solution causes to deprotonation of hydroxyl and phosphate function groups of CaHA surface and the electrostatic attraction between CaHA and CRe weakened. However, the pH values of solution lower than pHpzc, cause to the positive surface charge of absorbent because of the protonation
process [60] that makes stronger attraction between the positively charged surface of the absorbent and the negatively charged groups of the dye along with the increasment of CR adsorption (see Fig. 3(b)). Similar results were previously reported about CR adsorption on other adsorbents [56,61].

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Effect of contact time and initial dye concentration
sections.text: The effect of different initial dye concentrations (i.e. 40, 60, 100, and 150 ppm) and the contact time on the CR dye absorption onto 2 g/L CaHA nanoparticles dosage amount at pH ¼ 6 is depicted in Fig. 3(c). Increasing of the initial CR concentration is, enhancing in the adsorption capacity, raising the percentage removal efficiency of dye, and vice versa, that the initial adsorbed concentration of CR increases from 20 to 54 mg/g. The almost rapid increasing of adsorption occurs for the first 5e10 min that then proceeds slowly to reaching equilibrium about 30min for all of the studied solutions of different initial dye concentrations. The first part of rapid adsorption is because of the accessibility of the positive sites of the adsorbent, leading to electrostatic adsorption of the anionic CR dye. Regarding to contact time study, 30 min is enough to gain equilibrium that the next adsorption experiments were done at 30 min contact time. The same results have been reported within the percentage adsorption of dyes and organic compounds onto the various adsorbents [62,63].

sections.heading: 3.3. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
In order to optimize the plant of wastewater treatment, the effect of contact time on adsorption capacity of synthesized CaHA for 100 ppm concentration of CR solution with pH 6 was carried out (the results show in Fig. 4(a)). For this purpose, studying the kinetics parameters influencing on the dye adsorption rate, give important data for modeling the adsorption reactions. As discussed above increasing contact time causes to raising of the removal efficiency because of more available time for CR dye to interact with adsorption sites of the surface or inside of the adsorbent. It took 30 min achieving to equilibrium (see Fig. 3(c)). The adsorption process of a dye on a solid adsorbent can explained through three steps: (1) diffusion from solution to the external surface of the adsorbent, (2) diffusion of dye through the pores from external to internal structure of adsorption sites of the adsorbent, and (3) uptake of adsorbed dye. The last step should be rapid however steps 1 and 2 are the rate determining steps [64]. Therefore, to investigate the kinetics and mechanism of CR adsorption on solgel derived CaHA, the pseudoefirst order, pseudoesecond order, Elovich, Bangham, and intraparticle diffusion kinetic models were used to describe the experimental data. The related calculated kinetic parameters presented in Fig. 4(bef) along with the results listed in Table 1. Each model is expressed as follow:
(1) Pseudoefirst order model:
log (qeeqt) ¼ log qeek1 t (9)
(2) Pseudo-second-order model:
t / qt ¼ (1 / k2 qe2) þ t / qe (10)
(3) Elovich model:
qt ¼ (1 / b) ln (ab) þ (1 / b) ln t (11)
(4) Bangham model:
ln qt ¼ ln kb þ (1 / M) ln t (12)
(5) Intraparticle diffusion model:
qt ¼ kdif t0.5 þ C (13)
where qe and qt (mg g 1) are the adsorbed amount of dye over the surface of adsorbent at equilibrium and at time t (min), respectively. k1 and k2 (mg min g 1) are the pseudoefirst order and pseudoesecond order rate constants. a (mmol g 1 min 1) is the initial adsorption rate and b (g mmol 1) is the desorption constant. M and kb are the related constant of Bangham model. kdif (mg g 1 min 0.5) is the intraparticle diffusion rate constant. The values for
rate constants k1, k2, kb, kdif and linear fitting results calculated from the respective plots, were shown in Fig. 4 and tabulated in Table 1.
The experimental data indicates the satisfactory of secondeorder kinetic model for adsorption rate of CR dye (R2 ¼ 0.9902). Therefore, the main rate determining step should be chemisorption, that adsorption process controlled by the chemical reaction between adsorbent and adsorbate [65]. Actually, the calculated qe from secondeorder kinetic model was 72.99 mg g 1 which is in agreement with the experimental result (73.55 mg g 1). Moreover, according to pseudoesecond order model the boundary layer resistance was not a rateelimiting step [66]. Moreover, the adsorption rate usually governed by intraparticle mass transport. Therefore, investigation of diffusion mechanism within this
diffusion model should be informant (see Fig. 4 (f)). Linear fitting results of the adsorption of CR on CaHA show that intraparticle process could be another rate determining step of CR removal by CaHA (see Fig. 4(f)). However, the related plot (Fig. 4(f)) indicates that dye adsorption reaction proceeds through following steps [67] (i) at first adsorption of dye on boundary or external layer of adsorbant about 29 min; (ii) next gradual adsorption through intraparticle diffusion about 50 min; (iii) and the final stage is equilibrium adsorption. Similar observations about adsorption of CR on another adsorbents reported by others [56,61].

sections.heading: 3.4. Adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
The adsorption process proceeds until achieving the dynamic equilibrium between the adsorbed adsorbate on the surface of adsorbent and the remaining one in the solution. The adsorption isotherms with studying the relationship of these two amounts provide useful physicochemical information about the quality of adsorption process and describing the interactions of adsorbate onto the adsorbent surface. There are several adsorption models that analyze the experimental equilibrium results. Herein, Henry, Langmuir, Freundlich, and, Temkin isotherm models were used at 298, 308, and 318 K to describe the CR adsorption behavior onto the calcined CaHA as follow:
(1) Henry equation:
qe ¼ KH Ce (14)
(2) Langmuir equation:
1/ qe ¼ (1 / (b qm Ce)) þ 1 / qm (15)
(3) Freundlich equation:
ln qe ¼ ln KF þ (1 / n) ln Ce (16)
(4) Temkin equation:
qe ¼ (RT / bT) (ln Ce þ ln AT) (17)
where qm and qe (mg/g) are the maximum monolayer and equilibrium capacities of adsorption, respectively. KH and KF are the constants relating to the intensity and capacity of adsorption. Ce
(mg/L) is the equilibrium concentration of CR in solution, b is the Langmuir equilibrium coefficient (L/mg), the constant n as an empirical parameter shows the favorability of the adsorption process, and AT and bT are the equilibrium constants corresponding to the heat and binding energy of adsorption process. These four current isotherm models depicted in Fig. 5 and the respective calculated parameters from the slope and intercept are presented in Table 2. The Langmuir isotherm supposes that the adsorbate covers a monolayer on the homogeneous sites of the adsorbent which there is no interaction between adsorbed molecules on the neighboring positions. Therefore, b as adsorption intensity shows the affinity of binding site. The Freundlich model unlike the Langmuir undertakes the adsorption of adsorbate to heterogeneous surface of adsorbent, therefore at first the stronger binding sites occupied then with increasing the degree of occupied sites the strength of binding decreases [68]. For experimental results with 1/ n values that are below 1, the favorable adsorption can be concluded. In the other hand, the smaller 1/n value represents a heterogeneous surface of adsorbent while the closer or equal value to one indicates the more homogeneous binding sites of adsorbent. Temkin isotherm explains the interactions of adsorbenteadsorbate somehow the heat of adsorption of adsorbate molecules (function of temperature) on the adsorbate surface would linearly decrease [69,70].
According the correlation coefficient, the experimental data of equilibrium adsorption of CR was well fitted Langmuir isotherm (R2 ¼ 0.9979 at 298 K; R2 ¼ 0.9985 at 308 K; R2 ¼ 0.9918 at 318 K). One can conclude that the CR dye covers a homogeneous monolayer on the surface of CaHA nanoeparticle. Regarding the parameters of Langmuir model, the maximum adsorption capacity of calcined CaHA for CR decreased along with the increase of temperature. It can be explained as that increasing the temperature results in loosing of some bonds of adsorbateeadsorbent or rupturing some of functional groups of adsorbent that causes to disappearing of some active adsorption sites of its surface. The obtainedmaximum adsorption capacity of synthesized CaHA for CR was 487.80 mg/g at 298 K. Hall et al. [71] express the favorability of an adsorption reaction according the Langmuir model using a dimensionless constant RL (Hall separation factor) that calculated in the below equation:
RL ¼ 1 / (1 þ b C0) (18)
where C0 is the highest initial concentration of dye in the solution (mg/L). The values of RL reveal that the isotherms is irreversible (RL ¼ 0), unfavourable (RL > 1), favorable (0 < RL < 1), or linear (RL ¼ 1) [72]. Herein, these calculated values (for C0 ¼ 100 mg/L) within the range of 0 < RL < 1 as 0.2058, 0.2646, and 0.2364 at 298, 308, and 318 K, respectively (see Table 2). Therefore, the adsorption of CR onto calcined CaHA is favorable. However, 0 < 1/n < 0.5 shown that CR was facile for adsorption on calcined CaHA. Moreover, the correlation coefficient (R2) of Temkin model were higher than other two models (Henry and Freundlich) as more than 0.9150 at the three temperatures means heat plays key role in the adsorption process.

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption thermodynamics
sections.text:
In order to evaluate the influence of temperature on the adsorption process, calculating the thermodynamic parameters including the enthalpy (DH0), the Gibbs free energy (DG0), and the entropy (DS0) is useful. For the equilibrium state, these parameters can be calculated by the following equations:
DG0 ¼ eRT ln Kd (19)
where R (8.314 Jmol 1 K 1) is the universal gas constant, T (K) is the absolute temperature in Kelvin and Kd is the thermodynamic equilibrium constant. Kd values at different temperatures were obtained by plotting ln qe/Ce vs qe and extrapolating to zero value of qe (see Fig. 6(a)) [for more information see Ref. [73]]. The values of standard enthalpy and entropy of the adsorption can be evaluated from the slope and intercept of a linear plot of ln Kd vs 1/T (see
Fig. 6(b)). The related values of calculated DG0, DH0, and DS0 were listed in Table 3. The negative values of the all estimated DG0 indicate the adsorption process is spontaneous and thermodynamically favorable. The obtained results between 20 and 0 kJ/ mol suggests that the related adsorption reaction proceeds through the physisorption mechanism [74]. Actually, the low value of DS0 confirms that the interactions between adsorbent and molecules of adsorbate were physical [75]. Moreover, the negative value of DH0 shows that CR adsorption on this new synthesized CaHA was an exothermic process that became more favorable at lower temperatures. Additionally, the negative value of standard entropy suggests that the adsorbed CR molecules over the surface of calcined CaHA are better organized in comparison with those in solution. The relatively low value of entropy indicates that the interactions between adsorbent and adsorbate molecules should be physical.

sections.heading: 3.6. Performance evaluations
sections.text:
The maximum capacities of adsorption of the new calcined CaHA compound and reported values of other adsorbents for calculated of CR dye removal using Langmuir isotherm are listed in Table 4. According to the herein obtained qm of calcined CaHA in comparison to the other reported adsorbents of CR it can be revealed that this new synthesized compound is an effective adsorbent within the eliminating of CR from aqueous solutions, being as alternative about removing the CR dye from industrial wastewaters (see Table 4). Moreover, adsorption of CR by calcined CaHA reaching to equilibrium condition was very rapid as
immediately for 20 ppm and near 2 min for 40 and 60 ppm that reached, that made it as a good adsorbent candidate in treatment of economical wastewater. The importance of the present study is to obtain maximum adsorption capacities at ambient temperature while for many of the reported adsorbents they have changed pH or temperatures to attain maximum adsorption capacity of the adsorbents (see Table 4).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In the present study, the nano particles of a new CaHA through an easy low temperature sol-gel method including new conditions was first synthesized and then the structural evolution and particle size evaluation using XRD, FTIR, DTA, SEM, and TEM analyses investigated. However, sol-gel approach results in particles agglomeration that causes the small particles to be overlooked. The modified Scherrer's equation and TEM images show the determined 25 nm as the average of particle size. The synthesized CaHA well performed the CR adsorption as the process was very rapid and reached to steady state during 2 min. The adsorption of CR on CaHAwas more favored at lower temperatures and pH of solution. The maximum capacity of adsorption of CR for CaHA at 298 K was determined 487.80 mg/g that could be well fitted by Langmuir
model with R2 being higher than 0.9. According to the kinetic studies the experimental data fitted with pseudo second order kinetic model. Moreover the calculations of thermodynamic illustrated that the adsorption naturally was physisorption, exothermic, and spontaneous. NBO calculations show the maximum electron density on oxygen atoms of CR that make the electrostatic interactions governing the main adsorption mechanism by CaHA. One important point should be concluded that this new synthesized sol gel derived CaHA can be employed as low cost and biocompatible effective adsorbent for removing of CR from industrial wastewater.
